ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Bashas' Distribution Center facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained at the facility and updated as necessary.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage. 



Bashas' Distribution Center maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated as needed.



Bashas' Distribution Center has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration operation and maintenance firm.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Bashas' Distribution Center to evacuate and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency.  The refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance.  



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The facility including the ammonia refrigeration system at Bashas' Distribution Center was constructed in 1991.  Expansions of the facility have occurred in 1998, 2003, and in 2005 with the most recent expansion incorporating an ice cream freezer extension.  The Bashas' Distribution Center is located at 200 South 56th Street in Chandler, Arizona 85226.  The system was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local regulations including the Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes. 



The Bashas' Distribution Center facility receives and distributes food and food product

s to the following retail grocery outlets:  Bashas', Food City, and AJ's Fine Foods. 



The two ammonia refrigeration systems are used for warehouse cold storage, including dock operations and freezer storage.  The initial system maintains an inventory of approximately 12,800 pounds of ammonia with a maximum capacity of 13,000 pounds of ammonia, and the second refrigeration system is designed for a maximum inventory of 20,000 pounds of ammonia. 



Each refrigeration system utilizes a separate engine room in which most of the refrigeration equipment, including vessels, pumps, and compressors are housed. Condensers are mounted on the roof of each engine room and the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY



?    Worst Case Release Result Summary



South Refrigeration System Scenario Description: In reviewing the largest vessels and pipping (both indoors and outdoors), the vessel found to have the largest quantity in the South Refrigeration System is the Control Pressure Receiver (SCPR). The SCPR vessel is located in the South Mechanical Room and has a 66" diameter x 15' overall height. At a liquid level of 80% by volume, the SCPR vessel (rated for 300 psig MAWP) will contain an ammonia charge of approximately 5,033.1 pounds. The enclosure of the ammonia engine room provides a passive mitigation that limits the release rate to the atmosphere. The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F visibility. The EPA's RMP*COMP software was used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions. This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors. No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.  



North Refrigeration System Scenario Description: In reviewing the largest vessels and pipping (both indoors and outdoors), the vessel found to have the largest quantity in the North Refrigeration System

is the High Stage Suction Accumulator (HTA). The HTA vessel is located in the North Mechanical Room and has a 84" diameter x 15'10" overall height. At a liquid level of 80% by volume, the HTA vessel (rated for 250 psig MAWP) will contain an ammonia charge of approximately 8,768.9 pounds (see Attachment 2). The enclosure of the ammonia engine room provides a passive mitigation that limits the release rate to the atmosphere. The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F visibility.  The EPA's RMP*COMP software was used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions. This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors. No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.  





?    Alternative Case Release Result Summary



In selecting the scenario modeled for this study, the facility's five year accident history was considered. No accidental releases were identified which resulted in a release of ammonia in great enough quantity as to cause a concentration off ammonia off-site above the toxic endpoint. An alternative, more likely, to occur scenario was selected. This Alternative-Case scenario was be applied to both the North Refrigeration System and the South Refrigeration System.



    Scenario Description: An ammonia delivery truck is present at the facility to recharge the system. During the recharge process an ammonia transfer line breaks causing a release of liquid ammonia on the ground. Following the Bashas' Standard Operation Procedure - Ammonia Delivery Procedures (SOP-32), the ammonia delivery technician shuts down delivery and evacuates the area. The approximate duration of the release was six (6) minutes. The release was a liquid release, with liquid then boiling off into a vapor when exposed to atmosphere. Based on the flow rate of the delivery and the duration of release an estimated 500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia were released. The meteo

rological conditions used were 2.77 meters per second wind speed (based on NOAA atmospheric data for the previous five years) and B stability. The program ALOHA was used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in rural conditions. This release reaches offsite and may impact population receptors. No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release. 



ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Bashas' Distribution Center ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features. Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of each system. For example, the Bashas' Distribution Center facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. 



Bashas' maintains an on-going contract with a professional refrigeration service firm. The refrigeration contractors make regular preventative maintenance visits to the facility, ensuring the refrigeration equipment is maintained in a good state of repair. Major repairs are competed on a priority basis; ensuring safety is a top priority.



The Bashas' Distribution Center facility including the ammonia refrigeration systems were designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems. These safety features in each system include a water diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the machine room as well as sensors in selected cold storage areas, and automatic shutdown systems. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the machine room (condensers).  All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves to protect the vessel's integrity during extreme pressure conditions. 



In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrig

eration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110 "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems" is used as the basis for the facility's maintenance program.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no ammonia accidents at the facility, including any reportable releases during the previous 5 year period (since 2003).  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Bashas' Distribution Center has an Emergency action plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detail in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document as well as in the facility's general Emergency Response Plan: a self-contained document located and maintained onsite.  These plans were designed to meet the following objectives:



1.    To save lives

2.    To minimize and avoid injuries

3.    To protect the environment

4.    To minimize property damage



Bashas' Distribution Center maintains a safety committee whose member are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The plans provide the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  These plans are reviewed and updated at least once per year.  These plans were reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.  



Bashas' Distribution Center has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contract refrigeration operation and maintenance firm. In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Bashas' Distribution Center to evacuate and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency. The refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY    



A three year compliance audit was completed in February of

2017 and the five year process hazard analysis was completed in April of 2019 resulting in multiple recommendations to improve safety and implementation of the Risk Management Programs. Formalization and acceptance of all recommendations proposed in during the audits were completed in the months following the compliance audit and process hazard analysis. Bashas' Distribution Center is committed to maintaining and improving the ammonia refrigeration systems to ensure the safe operation of the systems.
